properties.Name: IncomeStatement
properties.Description:
The income statement details the amount of income and how it was earned. 

It is a summary of the revenue, expenses and net income/net loss of the legal entity for a specific period where:

REVENUE = The increase in capital as a result of the sale of goods or services provided by the business.   The revenue is equal to the cash, accounts receivable and other assets gained in compensation for goods sold or services rendered.

EXPENSES = The decrease in capital that is the result of the business' revenue-producing operations.   The expenses amount is equal to the value of the goods and services used up or consumed in obtaining the revenue.

NET INCOME = The increase in capital that is the result from profitable operation of the business during the period.   It is the excess of revenues over expenses for the accounting period.

NET LOSS = The decrease in capital resulting from the operations of the business.   It is the excess of expenses over revenue for the operating period.

The statement of retained earnings is often combined with the income statement or incorporated into the statement of shareholder's equity (see bottom of this example).

It is a record of its earnings or losses for a given period. It shows all of the money a company earned (revenues) and all of the money a company spent (expenses) during this period. 

It documents the changes in the balance sheet retained earnings account from one period to the next (see Stockholders Equity Retained Earnings).

It also accounts for the effects of some basic accounting principles such as depreciation.

It is for a specific period of time, where the balance sheet is at a specific instance of time.

The Income Statement reports cash flows on the accrual basis or inflows measured as revenues and outflows measured as expenses.

Another name for the Income Statement is the Profit & Loss Statement.

Columns.Name: LegalEntityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Legal Entity.

Columns.Name: FinancialStatementId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Statement.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the financial statement is prepared.

Columns.Name: SalesOfGoodOrServicesAmount
Columns.Description: The sales of goods and services to customers.

Columns.Name: SalesReturnsAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of any returns or return credits from customers during the period.

Columns.Name: SalesDiscountsAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of sales discounts to customers during the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNetSalesAmount
Columns.Description: The increase in capital as a result of the sale of goods and services by the business.

Columns.Name: InventoryAmount
Columns.Description: The cost of goods sold attributed to inventory.

Columns.Name: PurchasesAmount
Columns.Description: The cost of goods sold attributed to purchases.

Columns.Name: GoodsAvailableForSaleAmount
Columns.Description: The cost of goods sold attributed to cost of goods available for sale.

Columns.Name: CostOfGoodsSoldAmount
Columns.Description: The cost of goods sold attributed to inventory.

Columns.Name: TotalCostOfGoodsSoldAmount
Columns.Description: The total costs of goods sold amount.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseSellingAndAdministrativeExpensesAmount
Columns.Description:
An operating expense is an expense arising in the normal course of running a business.

Selling and Administrative expenses relate to the sale of products or services and to the management of the business.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseAdvertisingAmount
Columns.Description: Advertising costs relate to the advertising function within marketing.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseLeasePaymentsAmount
Columns.Description: Lease payments include rentals of leased facilities etc.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseDepreciationAndAmortizationAmount
Columns.Description:
The cost of assets other than land are allocated over the assets service life rather than expensed in the year of purchase.

The cost allocation procedure is depreciation and is used to allocate the cost of the tangible fixed assets.

Amortization is the term applied to the cost expiration of intangible assets such as patents, copyrights, trademarks, licenses, franchises and goodwill.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseRepairsAndMaintenanceAmount
Columns.Description: Repairs and maintenance are the annual costs of repairing and maintaining the property, plant and equipment (fixed assets).

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseSalariesExpensesAmount
Columns.Description: Operating expenses for non-officer salaries during the period.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseOfficersSalariesExpenseAmount
Columns.Description: Operating expenses for officer salaries during the period.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseTravelExpensesAmount
Columns.Description: Operating expenses for travel expenses during the period.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseInsuranceExpensesAmount
Columns.Description: Operating expenses for insurance expenses during the period.

Columns.Name: OperatingExpenseTotalOperatingExpensesAmount
Columns.Description: The total of operating expenses for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNetIncomeFromOperationsAmount
Columns.Description: Income from operations is generated from running the primary business and excludes income from other sources.

Columns.Name: InterestExpenseAmount
Columns.Description: The amount reported by a company or individual as an expense for borrowed money.

Columns.Name: OtherExpensesAmount
Columns.Description: Other or miscellaneous expenses.

Columns.Name: TotalNetIncomeLossAmount
Columns.Description: The net income/loss reported for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalGrossProfitAmount
Columns.Description: Gross profit or sales profit is the difference between revenue and the cost of making a product or providing a service, before deducting overhead, payroll, taxation, and interest payments.

Properties.Description:
The income statement details the amount of income and how it was earned. 

It is a summary of the revenue, expenses and net income/net loss of the legal entity for a specific period where:

REVENUE = The increase in capital as a result of the sale of goods or services provided by the business.   The revenue is equal to the cash, accounts receivable and other assets gained in compensation for goods sold or services rendered.

EXPENSES = The decrease in capital that is the result of the business' revenue-producing operations.   The expenses amount is equal to the value of the goods and services used up or consumed in obtaining the revenue.

NET INCOME = The increase in capital that is the result from profitable operation of the business during the period.   It is the excess of revenues over expenses for the accounting period.

NET LOSS = The decrease in capital resulting from the operations of the business.   It is the excess of expenses over revenue for the operating period.

The statement of retained earnings is often combined with the income statement or incorporated into the statement of shareholder's equity (see bottom of this example).

It is a record of its earnings or losses for a given period. It shows all of the money a company earned (revenues) and all of the money a company spent (expenses) during this period. 

It documents the changes in the balance sheet retained earnings account from one period to the next (see Stockholders Equity Retained Earnings).

It also accounts for the effects of some basic accounting principles such as depreciation.

It is for a specific period of time, where the balance sheet is at a specific instance of time.

The Income Statement reports cash flows on the accrual basis or inflows measured as revenues and outflows measured as expenses.

Another name for the Income Statement is the Profit & Loss Statement.
